title: What does it mean when we say that a function is bounded? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let's do an example. Let's say [math]f(x)=x^3-2x^2+5x-10[/math]. You might notice that 2 is a root of [math]f(x)=0[/math] by plugging it in. A consequence is that we can factor out [math]x-2[/math] to get [math]f(x)=(x-2)(x^2+5)[/math]. What's left, [math]x^2+5[/math], is the [math]g(x)[/math] in the statement. Notice that [math]g(2)\neq0[/math]. Now instead consider the function [math]f(x)=(x-2)^2(x+7)[/math]. Here, 2 is a double root. Now, if we factor out [math]x-2[/math], we get [math]f(x)=(x-2)g(x)[/math], where [math]g(x)=(x-2)(x+7)[/math]. Here, [math]g(2)=0[/math], because 2 was not a simple root. It was a double root. The reason they say bounded is that they don't want to allow you to "factor" [math]f(x)=x^2+3[/math] as [math](x-2)\frac{x^2+3}{x-2}[/math] with [math]g(x)=\frac{x^2+3}{x-2}[/math]. In this example, f does not have a root at 2, so this factorization has to be invalid. Indeed, g blows up to infinity as x approaches 2.

It means it is limited by a constant, i.e. it's not blowing up to infinity anywhere. In this particular case, it's good to know since otherwise for  it could go to infinity and make an indeterminate form .  Still, this doesn't feel right. It was never stated that f is bounded itself. If it isn't, if it has some, say, poles, then this whole story is nil (i.e. you couldn't guarantee boundedness of g on the whole domain).
